poem:
the city exhales steam through neon veins  
Route 27324 hurtles, refusing the honk of honking geese  
they scatter like spilled oil under its wheels  

at every stop a low hum rattles the bones—  
a mechanical bird on each panel, wings of steel  
clattering secrets to the asphalt  

watching eyes in high-rise windows blink  
as if the pulse of the engine were their own  
voices surge and fracture in the aisle—  
a chorus of half-heard prayers, street slang, cigarette embers  

steel springs coil and snap  
every turn is a ritual sacrifice of inertia  
each journey is a negotiation with power—  
the driver’s silhouette an oracle behind the wheel  

dust motes dance in the headlights  
ghost geese flit behind cracked glass  
and the route, unbowed, thrums forward  
humming its strange lullaby to streetlight saints  

beneath the overpass the air shivers  
graffiti mouths chant beneath the roar of passing trucks  
the bus floats—a tether between sidewalks and sky  
its mechanical birds never resting, never roosting  

under flickering bulbs the passengers sway  
caught in a pulse that’s neither mercy nor malice  
but the neutral heartbeat of asphalt veins  
that guide steel wings through the city’s breath
